questions.text: Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the gallbladder is false?

choices.text: Valves of Heister are present around the neck of the gallbladder
Gall bladder has a very thick submucosal layer
Hartmann's pouch may hinder safe dissection of the cystic pedicle
Phrygian cap anomaly is not an indication for cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
The gallbladder does not have muscularis mucosa and submucosa. Those layers are absent in the gallbladder.

The mucosa of the cystic duct is arranged in spiral folds known as the valves of the Heister. The valves act to keep gallstones from entering the common bile duct in spite of distention and intraluminal pressure.

Hartmann’s pouch is a diverticulum that can occur at the neck of the gallbladder. It may obscure the cystic duct and Calot’s triangle during laparascopic surgical dissection.

The Phrygian cap is present in 2–6 percent of cholecystograms and may be mistaken for a pathological deformity of the organ. It is not an indication for cholecystectomy.

questions.text: While assisting a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallstones, the surgeon asks you to identify the Calot's triangle. Which of the following structures does not form the boundaries of this triangle?

choices.text: The inferior surface of the liver

questions.solution:
The inferior surface of the liver forms the boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle, not Calot’s triangle.

Calot's triangle is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within its boundaries. The cystic artery should be identified while performing a cholecystectomy to avoid damage to the extrahepatic biliary system.

Occasionally, there can be a tortuous course of the right hepatic artery in some patients. This is called Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump. It is an important anomaly that should be recognized in order to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries. 

Note: The cystic artery is one of the contents as well as forms the superior boundary of the Calot's triangle (originally described in 1891 by Jean-François Calot)

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: Which type of gallstones is most likely to be seen in the Asian population?
questions.solution:
The most common type of gallstone to be seen in the asian population is pigment stone (80%). The most common type of gallstone worldwide is mixed stone.

Three main types of gallstones include:

  • Cholesterol stones - They consist of cholesterol monohydrate crystals. Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for <10% of all cases.
  • Pigment stones (brown or black) contain <30% cholesterol:
    • Black stones - Made up of insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphate and calcium bicarbonate. They are associated with hemolysis, usually seen in hereditary spherocytosis or sickle cell disease.
    • Brown stones - Contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, and calcium stearate, as well as cholesterol. They are also associated with the presence of foreign bodies within the bile ducts, such as endoprostheses (stents), or parasites, such as Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.
  • Mixed stones.

The image below shows a resected specimen of the gallbladder with pigment stones.

Struvite stone (triple phosphate stone) is a type of renal calculi. It is made of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen of gallstones removed is given below. Which of the following is least likely to be a risk factor for the formation of this type of gallstone in her?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis is not a risk factor for the formation of cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis leads to the production of black pigment stones.

Obesity, high-caloric diets, prolonged fasting, certain medications (e.g., oral contraceptives), and resection of the terminal ileum result in increased secretion of cholesterol and supersaturation of bile. This enhances the lithogenicity of bile.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. CT scan of the abdomen revealed the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign. It is a characteristic sign seen in gallstones.

In gallstone, rarely, the center of the stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph called the Mercedes–Benz sign (triradiate sign) or seagull sign (biradiate sign).

questions.text: What percentage of gallstones are radio-opaque?
questions.solution:
Only 10% of gallstones are radiopaque.

Approximately 90% of renal stones, 10% of gall stones, and 5% of appendicoliths contain enough calcium to appear radiopaque on plain films.

Gallbladder diseases are regularly diagnosed by ultrasound because of the superficial location of the gallbladder and the absence of overlying bowel gas. Ultrasound has a high specificity and sensitivity for cholelithiasis. It is considered as the first test of choice for delineation of any biliary pathology. Stones appear acoustically dense and also produce an acoustic shadow. They also move with a change in posture. However, CT provides superior anatomic information and therefore is indicated when more anatomic delineation is required.

questions.text: While performing the HIDA scan in a patient with gallstones, the gallbladder was not visualized. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Non-visualization of the gallbladder in HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scan is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usually because a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by the stone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include:

  • Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back
  • Fever
  • Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia
  • Jaundice
  • Positive Murphy's sign
  • Positive Boas' sign

Murphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costal margin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line of the patient. The patient is then instructed to take a deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a ‘catch’ of breath, Murphy’s sign is said to be positive.

Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site of radiation of the pain to the back, typically, below the scapula.

USG and CT scans are helpful in establishing a diagnosis. The gold standard investigation of acute cholecystitis is the HIDA scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m ( 99mTc)-labeled derivative of iminodiacetic acid.

The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder is not visualized even after 4 hours.

 

Unlike bilirubin, iminodiacetic acid (IDA) compounds do not undergo conjugation in the hepatocytes. They are rapidly excreted into the bile. This enables excellent visualization of the bile ducts and gallbladder within 30–60 minutes of injection.

Since cystic duct obstruction initiates acute cholecystitis, there is non-visualization of the gallbladder 3 - 4 hours after the intravenous injection of 99m Tc-IDA. This is characteristic of acute cholecystitis. Thus visualization of the GB establishes cystic duct patency and rules out acute cholecystitis.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was admitted with right hypochondriac pain and vomiting. USG demonstrates a stone within the bile duct. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The presence of a stone within the bile duct is called choledocholithiasis. Murphy's sign is not seen in choledocholithiasis. It is seen in acute cholecystitis.

Clinical features of choledocholithiasis:

  • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, which may radiate to the back
  • Biliary colic
  • Vomiting
  • Dyspepsia
  • Flatulence
  • Food intolerance particularly to fatty foods
  • Altered bowel habits
  • Jaundice.

Other Murphy's in surgery:

Murphy's punch sign: This test is performed by the examiner using the fist to make jabbing thrusts over the costovertebral angle. The test is positive in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney.

The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Murphy's triad is associated with acute appendicitis.

  • Pain in the right illiac fossa
  • Vomiting
  • Fever

questions.text: According to the Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis, which of the following conditions is classified under moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
If the duration of complaints is >72 hours, the patient is classified as having moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis.

Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis
Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis
Associated with organ dysfunction
1. Cardiovascular dysfunction Hypotension* requiring treatment with dopamine >5 mcg/kg/min, or any dose of noradrenaline
2. Neurological dysfunction Decreased level of consciousness
3. Respiratory dysfunction PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300
4. Renal dysfunction Oliguria; serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
5. Hepatic dysfunction Prothrombin time (PT-INR)>1.5
6. Hematological dysfunction  Platelet count, <100,000/mm3
Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitis

Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following:

  1. Elevated white blood cell count (>18,000/mm3)
  2. Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant
  3. Duration of complaints >72 hours
  4. Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)
Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitis 

Does not meet the criteria of grade II or III acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gall bladder, making cholecystectomy a safe and low-risk operative procedure.


Acute cholecystitis is treated by keeping the patient nil per oral (NPO), administering intravenous fluids, analgesics, and IV antibiotics.

The timing of surgery in acute cholecystitis remains controversial:

  • If the patient presents within 3 days, emergency cholecystectomy is done.
  • If the patient presents after 3 days, conservative management is done initially. Once the inflammation subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy).

Recent edition update: *In the 27th edition of Bailey and Love, it is incorrectly mentioned that the cardiovascular dysfunction is hypertension requiring dopamine ≤5 mcg/kg/min.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension and ischemic heart disease presented with fever, nausea and right upper abdominal pain for the past 2 days. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has a right upper quadrant palpable mass. Laboratory findings are mentioned below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Cr: 3.2 mg/dL; INR: 2.1; Platelet count: 60,000/mm3; TLC: 18000/mm3

USG abdomen: Enlarged edematous gallbladder with pericholecystic fluid, biliary radicles are normal in diameter

choices.text: Percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by interval cholecystectomy
Conservative management, followed by delayed cholecystectomy after 6 weeks

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of severe acute cholecystitis (grade III) based on Tokyo Consensus Guideline. Patients who have multiple comorbidities and present with severely acute cholecystitis should ideally undergo USG guided percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized..

Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis
Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis
Associated with organ dysfunction
1. Cardiovascular dysfunction Hypotension* requiring treatment with dopamine >5 mcg/kg/min, or any dose of noradrenaline
2. Neurological dysfunction Decreased level of consciousness
3. Respiratory dysfunction PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300
4. Renal dysfunction Oliguria; serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
5. Hepatic dysfunction Prothrombin time (PT-INR)>1.5
6. Hematological dysfunction  Platelet count, <100,000/mm3
Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitis

Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following:

  1. Elevated white blood cell count (>18,000/mm3)
  2. Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant
  3. Duration of complaints >72 hours
  4. Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)
Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitis 

Does not meet the criteria of grade II or III acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gall bladder, making cholecystectomy a safe and low-risk operative procedure.

Management of cholecystitis

  • Nil per oral (NPO)
  • IV fluids
  • Analgesics
  • IV antibiotics
  • Surgery
    • Grade III 
      • with comorbidities - a percutaneous cholecystostomy can be performed by a radiologist under ultrasound guidance. An interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized.
      • without comorbidities - unless the patient is extremely hemodynamically unstable, operative intervention (cholecystectomy) should be performed.
    • Grade I-II 
      • presenting within 3 days - emergency cholecystectomy is done.
      • presenting after 3 days - conservative management is done initially. Once the inflammation subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy).

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with complaints of right upper quadrant pain, fever and nausea. On examination, there is tenderness over the right upper quadrant. CT scan revealed the following finding. What is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT scan showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder are diagnostic of acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Clostridia species are the most commonly implicated organisms in acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Other causative organisms include E. coli and anaerobic streptococci.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation in the lumen or wall.

Clinical features include:

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Presence of crepitus during physical examination

On imaging, the condition is diagnosed when there is a radiographic demonstration of air in the gallbladder wall +/- biliary ducts.

Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients. Tube cholecystostomy is done for patients who are not suitable for surgery.

The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with an X-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall.

Note: E. coli is the most commonly implicated organism in acute emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A patient in the burns ward complains of right hypochondriac pain and fever. USG reveals a thickened, hyperemic gallbladder with sludge formation surrounded by pericholecystic fluid but no gallstones. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: CT-guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice
It has a high mortality rate
E. coli is the causative agent

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG findings point to a diagnosis of acalculous cholecystitis. E. coli is not a causative agent of acalculous cholecystitis. 

Acute and chronic inflammation of the gallbladder can occur in the absence of stones and are referred to as acalculous cholecystitis.

It is mainly seen in critically ill patients and those recovering from major surgery, trauma, and burns. It has a high mortality rate.

The bacterial infections of the gallbladder causing acalculous cholecystitis include:

  • Leptospira
  • Streptococcus
  • Salmonella
  • Vibrio cholerae

Clinical features are similar to that of acute calculous cholecystitis, such as:

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever
  • Positive Murphy's sign
  • Leukocytosis
  • Sepsis

A USG demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, biliary sludge, pericholecystic fluid, and the presence or absence of abscess formation. HIDA scan shows a non-visualization of the gallbladder. 

Acalculous cholecystitis requires urgent intervention. Percutaneous ultrasound or CT-guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice for these patients, as they are usually unfit for surgery.

Cholecystectomy is performed after the patient has recovered from the underlying illness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady was incidentally found to have gallstones during the abdominal ultrasound. She is otherwise healthy and does not complain of any symptoms. In which of the following clinical scenarios you will not advise her for prophylactic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis is indicated only when gallstones >3 cm.

Indications for consideration of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic patients:

  • Risk factors for carcinoma
  • Choledochal cysts
  • Gallbladder adenomas
  • Porcelain (calcified) gallbladder
  • Solitary gallbladder polyp larger than 1 cm
  • Choledocholithiasis
  • Gallstones >3 cm
  • The patient lives in a remote location from a healthcare facility
  • Sickle cell disease/spherocytosis
  • Transplant or immunosuppressant therapy.

Note: Some books also mention "Prophylactic cholecystectomy is indicated in asymptomatic cholelithiasis when gallstones >2 cm."

questions.text: Medical therapy for gallstones using ursodeoxycholic acid will be considered in all of the following conditions, except:

choices.text: If the size of the cholesterol stone is < 10mm
If the patient has biliary pain without any complications
In the presence of radio-opaque cholesterol gallstones

questions.solution:
Medical therapy using ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) for gall stones is indicated for radiolucent cholesterol stones.

Selection criteria for oral bile acid dissolution therapy:

  • Symptomatic patients without complications
  • Patients with normal gallbladder functioning and a patent cystic duct
  • Patients with radiolucent stones and diameter < 10 mm

Stones >10 mm in size rarely dissolve. Patients with cholesterol gallstone disease who develop recurrent choledocholithiasis after cholecystectomy should be on long-term treatment with UDCA. The dose of UDCA should be 10–15 mg/kg per day.

Pigment stones are non-responsive to UDCA therapy.

Related Pearl: Prerequisites for Medical Therapy in Cholelithiasis

  • Functioning gallbladder
  • Radiolucent stones
  • Stones <10mm
  • Cholesterol stones

questions.text: A patient with symptomatic gallstones but refusing surgery is at risk of developing all of the following complications except:
questions.solution:
Diverticulosis is not a complication due to gallstones.

Clinical complications due to gallstones include the following:

  • Biliary colic
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Chronic cholecystitis
  • Empyema of the gallbladder
  • Mucocele
  • Perforation
  • Biliary obstruction
  • Acute cholangitis
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Intestinal obstruction (gallstone ileus).

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding the mucocele of the gallbladder?

choices.text: Caused due to prolonged obstruction of cystic duct
Early cholecystectomy needs to be done
Obstruction can be seen in the neck of the gallbladder
A tender, non palpable gallbladder is characteristic of this condition

questions.solution:
The gallbladder is palpable but non-tender in the mucocele of the gallbladder.

Mucocele of the gallbladder results from prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct, usually by a large solitary calculus. The obstructed gall bladder lumen is progressively distended by mucus (mucocele) or by a clear transudate (hydrops) produced by mucosal epithelial cells.

It is usually asymptomatic, although chronic right upper quadrant pain may also occur. On examination, a visible, easily palpable, non-tender gallbladder, sometimes extending from the right upper quadrant into the right iliac fossa may be seen.

Ultrasonography is helpful for the diagnosis.

Early cholecystectomy needs to be done, because empyema, perforation, or gangrene may complicate the condition.

The image below shows mucocele of the gallbladder.

The image below shows empyema of the gallbladder.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of cholelithiasis was rushed to the casualty with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. Her  X-ray erect abdomen is given below. Which statement is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with Rigler's triad
Jejunum is the most common site of obstruction
CT scan is the investigation of choice
Enterotomy is done in the absence of strangulation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. The distal ileum is the most common site to be obstructed in gallstone ileus because it tapers before entering the cecum.

Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation.

Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler's triad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes:

  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia)
  • Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa)

The investigation of choice is the CT scan. Pneumobilia is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliary tree.

Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and analgesics. 

If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by:

  • Milking the stone beyond ileocaecal junction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Enterotomy to remove the stone

If there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done.

Cholecystectomy should be performed to avoid future complications. Fistula closure can be performed along with cholecystectomy or it can be performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

A large gallstone causing gallstone ileus is shown below.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presented with colicky abdominal pain, jaundice and generalized pruritus. She has a palpable gallbladder. Which of the following is the least likely cause?

choices.text: Stone impacted in the cystic duct
Stone impacted in the fundus of gallbladder
Stone impacted within the gallbladder and common bile duct
Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
A stone impacted within the fundus of the gallbladder is least likely to cause jaundice with a palpable gallbladder.

According to Courvoisier's law, the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, is unlikely due to gallstones. It usually indicates a possibility of carcinoma in the head of the pancreas. However, apart from a cancer in the pancreatic head, certain other conditions may also cause a palpable gallbladder in presence of jaundice. For example,

  • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
  • Primary CBD stone
  • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 
  • Mirizzi's syndrome (an impacted gallstone in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation, causing common bile duct (CBD) obstruction, jaundice and a palpable gallbladder)

These are considered exceptions to Courvoisier's law.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain, vomiting and jaundice. Her ALP and direct bilirubin levels were raised. She had undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy 1 year back. On USG there is dilatation of biliary radicles. Which of the following is the ideal management for this patient?

choices.text: Laparoscopic exploration of common bile duct
Open surgical exploration of common bile duct
Addition of ursodeoxycholic acid, followed by repeat USG after 10 days

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of choledocholithiasis. When diagnosed postoperatively (after cholecystectomy), it should be managed with ERCP + sphincterotomy.

Stone detected within 2 years after cholecystectomy is called retained stone. Stone detected more than 2 years after cholecystectomy is considered recurrent stone.

CBD stone and GB stone detected before cholecystectomy:

  • ERCP+Sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy after a few days should be done.

CBD stone detected during surgery (intraoperatively):

  • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy + laparoscopic CBD exploration should ideally be done in the same sitting to avoid the need for additional operative sitting and anaesthesia.
    • A transcystic approach is preferred usually.
    • If there is a small, friable cystic duct; numerous (more than eight) stones in the common bile duct; and large stones (>1 cm), laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is performed.
    • If laparoscopic choledocholithotomy exploration is not feasible, it would necessitate the need for an open CBD exploration.
  • A T-tube is placed in the CBD after laparoscopic choledocholithotomy or open CBD exploration. It is followed by a cholangiography to exclude retained stone.

CBD stone detected after surgery:

  • Endoscopic removal (ERCP) with sphincterotomy is usually the management of choice.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue. On imaging, she was found to have a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones in it. A large stone was also present in the common bile duct and the biliary tree is dilated. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
An 80-year-old woman with imaging showing a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones and a stone in the bile duct is suggestive of chronic cholelithiasis with choledocholithiasis. ERCP is the next line of management for this patient. 

Choledocholithiasis is the presence of stone in the common bile duct (CBD) or biliary tree. It can be primary or secondary:  

  • Primary stones are formed in the CBD or biliary tree itself and are rare.
  • Secondary stones are passed from the gallbladder to the CBD. They are easier to manage than primary stones.

It can be an asymptomatic and incidental finding or present with features such as jaundice (most common), abdominal pain, and fatigue. When there is inflammation of the biliary tree (cholangitis), the patient will have intermittent pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot's triad). 

Investigations: 

  • Liver function tests will show elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. 
  • Abdominal ultrasound is the first imaging modality done and may show gallstones and dilated bile duct (>8 mm). 
  • CT is sensitive for CBD stones. It shows stones, location, ductal stricture or block, ductal dilatation, and intrahepatic biliary changes.
  • MRCP is highly sensitive and specific for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.

Management: 

  • ERCP with sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice, followed by the removal of stones using a dormia basket or placement of a stent.
  • Despite ERCP being an invasive procedure, it has the advantage of being both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure and is more suited for elderly patients who cannot tolerate anesthesia and surgery.

Other options: 

Option A: Cholecystectomy is not recommended for elderly patients, owing to the risk of old age and associated anesthetic and surgical complications.

Option C: Wait and watch approach can be done for asymptomatic patients, and patients with smaller stones.

Option D: CT is sensitive for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: What is the best investigation in a patient suspected to have an impacted gallstone at the ampulla of Vater?
questions.solution:

questions.text:
Which of the following features are part of Reynold's pentad?

1. Altered mental status

2. Vomiting

3. Jaundice

4. Hypotension

5. Diaphoresis
questions.solution:
Vomiting and diaphoresis are not part of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad is seen in acute suppurative cholangitis.

Related Pearl: Charcot and Reynold's Triad

Charcot's triad - in acute cholangitis

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever with chills
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad - in acute suppurative cholangitis

  • Charcot’s triad + Altered mental status + Hypotension

questions.text: A jaundiced patient presented with complaints of colicky abdominal pain and itching all over the body. USG abdomen showed thickening of the gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid. MRCP showed extrinsic compression of the common bile duct, suggestive of Mirizzi syndrome. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, gallbladder, and the stone
Cystic duct obstruction will be present
Fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct

questions.solution:
A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception to Courvoisier's law.

Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include:

  • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
  • Primary CBD stone
  • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 
  • Mirizzi's syndrome

In Mirizzi’s syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. The gallbladder is distended and may be palpable.

ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 

Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. In patients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomy should be done.

If left untreated, a fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct (cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

Related Pearl: Mirizzi’s syndrome

Gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder producing CBD obstruction and jaundice.

 

  • ERCP, PTC, MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 
  • Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a resected specimen of a gallbladder with a polyp on the inner surface. 

Specimen of gallbladder carcinoma would include an en-bloc dissection of the gall bladder, surrounding liver tissue and regional lymph nodes (option D). In specimens of cholesterolosis, also known as strawberry gallbladder, the gall bladder would appear yellow and coarsely granular due to the presence lipid nodules (options A and B).

Gall bladder polyps are usually incidental findings during abdominal imaging. Most of them are benign and comprise cholesterol polyps, adenomyomas or inflammatory polyps. Adenomatous polyps are the most common neoplastic polyps. The majority of patients with polyps are stable and smaller polyps are kept under observation. Cholecystectomy is done for symptomatic patients (biliary colic, pancreatitis), patients >50 years, sessile polyps with thickening >4 mm and polyps >10 mm.

The risk factors for malignancy in an adenomatous polyp include age >50 years, size >10 mm, sessile polyp, documented increase in size, and coexistence with gallstones.

Other options: 

Option D: The gallbladder in a patient with carcinoma is removed via an en-bloc dissection with surrounding liver tissue along with regional lymph nodes. The given image below shows a cut surface of the resected gallbladder with a tumor at the neck along with liver bed involvement (marked by the red arrow). 

Options A and B: Cholesterolosis (strawberry gallbladder) is characterized by the accumulation of lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors and cholesterol esters) in the lamina propria of the gallbladder wall. The nodules are less than 1 mm in diameter and there is mucous villous hyperplasia, which gives it a coarse, yellow and granular appearance, giving it a strawberry-like appearance. The given images below show cholesterolosis.

Related Pearl: Indication for Cholecystectomy in Gallbladder Polyp

  • All symptomatic patients
  • All asymptomatic patients >50 years
  • Polyp of size >10 mm
  • Evidence of polyp growth on serial ultrasonography

questions.text: A 45-year old lady is found to have a gall bladder polyp of size 1.2cm on abdominal USG. She appears to be healthy and is asymptomatic. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution: Gallbladder polyps larger than 1 cm have an increased risk of malignancy and should be treated by performing a cholecystectomy.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows calcification of the gallbladder, also known as porcelain gallbladder. This condition is associated with the risk of gall bladder carcinoma. Cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice.

Extended cholecystectomy includes removal of the gall bladder with a 2 cm non-anatomical wedge of the liver and lymphadenectomy. It is performed for stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion, and stage II of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for gallbladder carcinoma, except:
questions.solution:
Adenomyomatosis is not a risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder.

Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition of the gallbladder characterized by hypertrophy of the mucosal epithelium. It invaginates into the thickened muscularis forming Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses.

Risk factors for carcinoma gallbladder:

  • Gallstones of size >3 cm (most important risk factor)
  • Porcelain gallbladder
  • Anomalous pancreato-biliary junction
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Adenomatous polyps
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Obesity
  • Salmonella typhii infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding gallbladder carcinoma?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Depth of invasion is the most important prognostic factor

questions.solution:
The most common type of gallbladder carcinoma is adenocarcinoma (80–90%). Squamous carcinomas also occur and are believed to arise from areas of mucosal squamous metaplasia.

Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. It is associated with a poor prognosis and is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosed when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones.

Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice is a late feature. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring.

The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan or MRI/Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.

A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PET scanning helps in detecting metastatic disease.

In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can also detect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage).

Related Pearl: TNM staging of Gallbladder Carcinoma

TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma according to the AJCC guidelines, 8th edition
T: Primary tumor
Tx Main tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No sign of a primary tumor
Tis Cancer is only in the epithelium and has not grown into deeper layers of the gallbladder
T1 Tumor invades the lamina propria or the muscle layer (muscularis)
T1a

Tumor invades the lamina propria
T1b Tumor invades the muscular layer
T2a Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the peritoneum (the lining of the abdominal cavity)
T2b Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the liver but has not invaded the liver
T3 Tumor invades the serosa and/or it has grown directly into the liver and/or one nearby structure like the stomach, duodenum, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver.
T4 Tumor invades the main blood vessels leading into the liver (portal vein or hepatic artery) or it has grown into 2 or more structures outside the liver
N: Lymph nodes involvement  
NX Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed 
N0 No spread to nearby lymph nodes 
N1 Spread to < 3 nearby lymph nodes
N2 Spread to >4 nearby lymph nodes 
M: Distant metastasis  
M0 No spread to distant sites
M1 Tumor spread to distant sites such as the liver, peritoneum, or the lungs

IIIB T1-3N1M0

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumor penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general):

TNM staging Treatment
T1a Simple cholecystectomy
T1b, T2, T3 Radical cholecystectomy
T4 Unresectable, chemotherapy and palliative nonsurgical therapy are provided
N1 Regional lymphadenectomy
N2 Radical cholecystectomy plus hepatopancreatic duodenectomy


If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy:

  • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would suffice
  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.
